Kane.Action: Estate and grounds neglected and overgrown, zoo animals isolated and enclosures abandoned, cottages boarded up and locked with heavy bars, moat stagnant and choked with weeds.
Allows the estate grounds, including golf links, zoo, and gardens, to fall into neglect and disrepair over a long period.
Maintains a large and architecturally complex castle dominating the landscape, showing initial capability in establishing a grand estate.

Kane papers scoop the world on the Armistice - publish, eight hours before competitors, complete details of the Armistice teams granted the Germans by Marshall Foch from his railroad car in the Forest of Compeigne.
For forty years appeared in Kane newsprint no public issue on which Kane papers took no stand.
No public man whom Kane himself did not support or denounce - often support, then denounce.
As a boy, personally attacked Walter P. Thatcher by striking him with a sled.
As a boy, personally attacks a trustee by striking him with a sled, showing impulsiveness and lack of control.
Is the subject of a major trust and fortune managed by experienced trustees, indicating his family’s wealth and potential for future competence.
Orates publicly in full ceremonial dress, declaring his patriotism as an American.
Shakes hands with people at the event.
Appears lonely and unhappy despite being in a lively nightclub with his second wife.
Charges down upon photographers, laying about him with his stick, smashing whatever he can hit.
Urged his country's entry into one war, opposed participation in another, influenced national politics and elections.
Lives alone in a never-finished, decaying pleasure palace, aloof and seldom visited.
Continues to direct his falling empire vainly, trying to sway a nation that has ceased to trust him.
Portrayed as a desolate figure in the sunshine, confined to a bath chair and swathed in rugs.
Continues to direct his falling empire vainly, attempting to sway the destinies of a nation that has ceased to listen or trust him.
Maintains control over his empire alone in his decaying pleasure palace despite decline.
Gave Arthur Ellis a chance to clean up Detroit, Chicago, and St. Louis.
Described by Arthur Ellis as having the talent of a mountebank, morals of a bootlegger, and manners of a pasha.
Contributed significantly to journalism and gave opportunities to others like Arthur Ellis.
Described as having the talent of a mountebank, the morals of a bootlegger, and the manners of a pasha, suggesting questionable ethics and style.
Almost succeeded in transforming journalism into a less secure, more commercialized profession.
Raised salaries for his employees.
Labor record criticized harshly by some, implying poor treatment of workers.
Gave Arthur Ellis his chance to clean up Detroit, Chicago, and St. Louis, showing initiative and influence.
Raised salaries and had a notable labor record, indicating some skill in managing people and resources.
Labor record criticized harshly ('ought to hang him up like a dog'), suggesting failures or mismanagement in labor relations.
Loved and hated by many, but his dying words 'Rosebud' suggest a private, possibly tender side.
Has people who loved him and people who hated him, indicating a polarizing personality.
Has a complex legacy that prompts deep investigation into his life and motivations, indicating he was a significant and impactful figure.
Dies with a mysterious last word 'Rosebud' that confounds those around him, suggesting an unresolved or enigmatic aspect to his character.
Deliriously happy and blissfully cavorting in the snow, oblivious to warnings from his mother.
Deliriously happy and running away in the snow, oblivious to warnings from his mother.
Quietly asks to stop the nonsense, asserting his wishes calmly.
Quietly asserts control by telling Jim to stop the nonsense, indicating calm confidence.
Allows Thatcher and Mrs. Kane to take charge of decisions about his education and estate without objection.
Plays energetically with snowballs, engaging in playful battle with imaginary adversaries.
Encourages imaginary comrades with spirited battle cries.
Throws snowballs but misses widely and falls while crawling toward the snowman.
Shows enthusiasm and confidence in play by rallying and encouraging a fight with the rebels.
Greets his mother warmly and tries to engage her with a playful comment about the snowman.
Follows others with shoulders thrown back like one who bears defeat bravely, showing resignation but no visible anger or bitterness.
Shoulders thrown back like one who bears defeat bravely, follows adults despite difficult family situation.
Engages in childish play (removing pipe from snowman) and talks about making teeth, showing innocence and lack of adult control.
Questions his mother about why she isn't coming on the trip, showing concern.
Refuses to shake hands with Thatcher and hits him with a sled instead.
Hits Mr. Thatcher in the stomach with the sled, showing defiance and physical assertiveness.
Questions adults about the trip and his future, showing curiosity and engagement.
Does not verbally respond to Thatcher's attempts to connect, indicating social or emotional resistance.
Kicks Thatcher in the ankle when he tries to touch him.
Throws himself on his mother and clings to her, crying and frightened.
Kicks Mr. Thatcher in the ankle when he tries to touch him.
Throws himself on his mother and cries out for her, showing fear and emotional vulnerability.
Addresses Thatcher and Bernstein politely, includes Thatcher as a devoted reader, and openly shares information with readers.
Publishes unverified sensational headline about enemy armada, challenges Thatcher's skepticism with a confrontational question.
Admits he doesn't know how to run a newspaper but tries everything he can think of.
Publishes an unproven headline about an enemy armada, showing reckless reporting.
Challenges Thatcher by asking if he can prove the armada isn't there, showing confidence but ignoring journalistic standards.
Welcomes Bernstein and openly shares internal issues with Thatcher, showing transparency and confidence.
Plans to send a sarcastic cable to correct false information, showing wit but possibly unprofessionalism.
Makes a witty, playful remark to Wheeler and shares laughter with others at the table.
Holds the door open for Thatcher and invites him into his office.
Engages in a tense discussion with Thatcher about the Enquirer's campaign, showing a confrontational attitude.
Composes a clever, confident message to Wheeler and promptly sends it, showing decisiveness and wit.
Invites Thatcher to his office to discuss a sensitive issue, demonstrating control and willingness to confront opposition.
Uses a strategic argument to unsettle Thatcher by implying he represents multiple interests, showing tactical thinking.
Expresses sympathy for underprivileged people and offers a donation to a committee against himself.
States it is his duty and pleasure to protect decent, hard-working people from exploitation.
Acknowledges his wealth and power but emphasizes responsibility to defend the underprivileged.
Starts to dance and hum quietly in front of Thatcher, showing a playful, informal side.
Dismisses Thatcher's concerns about financial loss from his philanthropic enterprise without argument.
Demonstrates awareness of his financial holdings and uses this knowledge to justify his actions and influence others.
Expresses a clear sense of purpose and responsibility as a publisher to protect the underprivileged, showing strategic thinking and confidence.
Fails to communicate effectively with Thatcher, who does not understand him and reacts with frustration, indicating a gap in persuasive or interpersonal skills.
Begins to dance and hum during a serious discussion, which may undermine his credibility and the seriousness of his position.
Acknowledges the financial cost of his philanthropic enterprise, showing some realism and acceptance of consequences.
Acknowledges losing a million dollars a year on the Enquirer but confidently accepts the long-term cost, showing awareness of financial realities and commitment to his vision.
Kane got control of his own money at twenty-five and knew what he wanted and got it.
Kane was hard to figure out even for close associates, showing complexity and unpredictability.
Built an opera house for Susie, showing a grand gesture of support.
Allowed his wife to perform despite her poor singing, and no one dared to criticize her, indicating possible indulgence or protectiveness.
Referred to as a 'big man' whose influence silenced critics, suggesting a controlling or intimidating presence.
Builds an opera house for Susie, showing ambition and investment in grand projects.
Supports Susie in a leading opera role despite her poor performance, indicating poor judgment or inability to critically assess talent.
Is described as a 'big man' in those days, implying influence and capability.
His friend Branford Leland leaves a sentence unfinished, and Bernstein hesitates to pressure Leland, suggesting possible interpersonal or leadership difficulties.
Greets Bernstein and staff, acknowledges their work on the show coverage.
Asks about the quality of the notice quietly and casually, showing interest but no warmth or coldness.
Checks thoroughly that the show was covered by every department and that the notice is good, showing attention to detail and oversight.
Appears casually confident and commands respect upon arrival, indicating leadership and control.
Sharply questions about unfinished work, shows impatience.
Crosses room and opens door to confront Leland directly.
Stands over Leland who has passed out from drinking, showing a face described as murderous.
Sharp questioning about the unfinished dramatic notice, quickly gathers information, and decisively goes to confront Leland directly.
Shows a serious, almost murderous expression upon seeing Leland passed out at his typewriter, indicating emotional disturbance but no immediate action to resolve the situation.
Dictates a harsh, negative review of Susan Alexander's acting, overriding Bernstein's reluctance.
Reads the critical review carefully, recognizes its negative tone, and takes control by dictating a stronger, more cutting review himself.
Shows some hesitation and silence before responding to the review, indicating possible internal conflict or uncertainty.
Writes a harsh, critical notice about the girl he loved, despite believing in her talent and ambition.
Ensures that other notices in his papers are kind to Susie, showing care in public portrayal.
Typing furiously late at night to finish a difficult notice, showing dedication and work ethic.
Writes a harsh, brutally honest notice about someone he loves, possibly to demonstrate integrity and honesty to a colleague.
His contradictory behavior of publicly supporting Susie while privately writing a harsh critique, indicating complexity and possible strategic thinking.
His actions confuse others, including Bernstein, who calls him 'hard to figure out,' suggesting unpredictability that may undermine clear competence.
Greets Carter and Leland politely, acknowledges reporters standing for him with a grin, and asks them to sit down.
Admits he doesn't have any plans yet for the newspaper.
Shows concern for Bernstein after he crashes into the doorway and calls him over politely.
Insists on working around the clock to improve news coverage, showing dedication and seriousness.
Takes over Carter's office and living space without much regard for Carter's feelings.
Engages with staff and discusses news stories, showing involvement and interest.
Decides to live in his office to oversee operations closely and insists on changing the newspaper to operate 24 hours a day, showing initiative and vision.
Works feverishly on copy while eating, demonstrating dedication and multitasking ability.
Questions why his newspaper missed an important front page story, showing attention to detail and concern for journalistic quality.

Pushes away plates after eating but still says 'I'm still hungry,' which could indicate restlessness or dissatisfaction, a minor negative indicator of emotional competence but not necessarily professional competence.
Insists on sensationalizing news by focusing on gossip and rumors to boost headlines.
Gently tries to persuade Carter to change the newspaper's editorial approach.
Orders a deceptive and aggressive tactic to pressure Mr. Silverstone, including threats and false detective identity.
Insists on pursuing sensational news to boost the paper's impact, showing strategic thinking about headlines and news value.
Directs a bold and somewhat manipulative plan to pressure Mr. Silverstone, demonstrating confidence and tactical skill.
Ignores Carter's objections about journalistic standards, indicating a possible disregard for ethical considerations or teamwork.
Looks at Leland with a fond nod of his head at Bernstein; Leland grins back.
Dismisses Mr. Carter abruptly despite Carter's polite objection.
Engages in light banter with Bernstein and Leland about newspaper pricing and new brooms.
Insists on remaking pages at the last minute despite staff objections.
Accepts Carter's resignation with a formal but distant expression of 'deepest regard'.
Insists on remaking the pages despite objections and time constraints, showing decisiveness and control.
Accepts Carter's resignation calmly and with dignity, maintaining authority.
Pushes for changes that others find impossible, risking operational disruption.
Turns his back on Mr. Carter, ignoring his attempt to speak.
Calmly insists on remaking pages despite imminent press deadline, showing determination but disregarding others' concerns.
Shoves forms off the table, scattering them on the floor, demonstrating impatience and disregard for others' work.
Insists on remaking the pages despite the tight deadline, confidently overriding objections and taking control of the situation.
Shoves the forms off the table, scattering them, showing decisive and forceful behavior to enforce his will.
Calmly negotiates the process of remaking the pages and proofing them, demonstrating clear planning and command.
Closes the window to reduce noise for colleagues, shows consideration.
Encourages and engages with colleagues after a long night, showing shared effort.
Expresses dissatisfaction with the day's work despite colleagues' optimism, indicating high standards but possibly dismissive of others' efforts.
Smiles with happy concentration when discussing his vision, showing enthusiasm and openness.
Leads his team to produce a newspaper edition despite being nearly four hours late, showing persistence and dedication.
Expresses dissatisfaction with the current paper and insists on making it more important and impactful, demonstrating vision and high standards.
Closes the window to reduce noise distractions before addressing his team, showing awareness and control of his environment.
Calls the day 'wasted' despite multiple front-page appearances, which could indicate unrealistic expectations or impatience.
Writes his own Declaration of Principles promising honest news and no interference from special interests, speaks with real conviction.
Takes initiative to write his own Declaration of Principles despite not having shorthand skills; shows conviction and clarity in his vision for honest news.
Starts multiple sentences with 'I', indicating a possible self-centered approach or lack of polished writing style.
Builds newspaper circulation from 26,000 to 62,000 copies, showing growth and expansion of his publication.
Oversees the growth of the newspaper's circulation from 31,000 to 62,000, indicating successful management and expansion.
Sits with colleagues (Leland and Bernstein) observing the circulation figures and the staff photo, showing engagement and pride in his enterprise.
Smiles while looking at the photograph of his staff, showing pride and appreciation.
Acknowledges the long effort to build the newspaper staff, showing respect for others' work.
Engages in casual, friendly conversation with Bernstein and Leland about the newspaper.
Acknowledges the long effort it took to build the newspaper staff and respects the achievement.
Shows confidence and pride in the newspaper's success and circulation figures.
Relies on others' opinions about the newspaper's quality without challenging or adding insight.
Welcomes new journalists warmly, praises their talent, and celebrates their success with applause and good salaries.
Organizes a lively party with music and dancers to entertain guests, showing a desire to share joy and fun.
Confidently addresses his staff, celebrates a major circulation milestone, and emphasizes hiring based on talent rather than loyalty.
Organizes a lively, well-planned social event with a band and performers to entertain guests, showing leadership and planning skills.
Drives the growth of the 'Enquirer' newspaper through personal drive and leadership, resulting in a large circulation and a reputation for having the greatest staff in the world.
Is shown enjoying himself dancing with multiple partners, indicating confidence and social ease.
Grinning over a suggestion for a cartoon titled 'Capitalistic Greed' that is highly dramatic and gruesome.
Arranging a sob sister's dress to look more seductive for a hot news item.
Grabbing a camera from a photographer at the scene of a dangerous tenement fire, positioning himself prominently.
Grabs camera from photographer in obvious position of danger during a tenement fire.
Leads a campaign through the 'Enquirer' that results in winning better fire equipment.
Presence at execution with photographers taking sensational pictures, possibly exploiting the event.
Thanks the official politely and responds courteously.
Promises Bernstein not to buy more paintings and not to interfere with the papers, showing consideration.
Leaves companions midway up the gangplank and calls back playfully, indicating a friendly and informal attitude.
Jokes about not keeping his promises, showing a lighthearted and sincere interaction.
Politely interacts with officials and companions, showing social ease and confidence.
Makes promises to avoid certain behaviors but immediately admits he won't keep them, showing self-awareness and control over his own decisions.
Rushes up the gangplank and calls back to companions, demonstrating energetic and assertive behavior.
Smiles and politely asks Bernstein to tell the staff to sit down after they rise to greet him.
Engages with staff and plans to thoroughly review work after vacation, showing involvement and responsibility.
Returns to the City Room looking clear-eyed, tanned, and well-dressed in new English clothes, projecting confidence and renewed energy.
Commands Bernstein to ask the staff to sit down, demonstrating leadership and control over the situation.
Plans to thoroughly review everything, especially the new papers, showing diligence and a methodical approach to work.
Approaches the nervous Society Editor gently and hesitatingly, asks her to treat the announcement fairly and normally, speaks softly and gently.
Takes initiative to personally ensure the society editor treats his announcement with normal priority despite being away for months.
Approaches the society editor hesitatingly and softly, showing some uncertainty in his manner.
Kisses Emily Norton publicly and waves to acquaintances, showing openness and affection.
Turns his attention away from Emily to the newspaper, showing possible distraction or lack of full engagement with his fiancée.
Publicly displays affection for his fiancée, showing confidence and social ease.
Focuses attention on the newspaper (the Enquirer) rather than his fiancée during a public moment, indicating a strong professional focus and awareness of his public image.
Kept his private greatness to himself, never gave himself away or anything away, lived on power and excitement of using it, had many opinions but no convictions.
Had a generous mind and many opinions, lived on power and the excitement of using it.
Never gave himself away or anything away, kept his private greatness to himself.
Did not believe in anything except himself, never had a conviction in his life.
Makes a speech praising talent over loyalty, aiming to inspire his staff to create the best newspaper.
Focuses on entertaining readers rather than telling the truth (as recalled by Leland).
Makes a confident speech emphasizing talent over loyalty to build the best newspaper in the world, inspiring applause.
Leland criticizes Kane as a bad newspaper man who entertained but never told the truth, implying poor journalistic integrity and skill.
Finishes his speech and whistles to start a lively party with band and chorus girls, creating a festive atmosphere.
Sits down with Leland and Bernstein, lighting a cigarette and engaging them in conversation.
Expresses enthusiasm about covering the war in a lighthearted, humorous way, showing camaraderie with colleagues.
Says 'If everybody's having fun, that's the way I want it.'
Invites Leland to join him at Georgie's, a madam's place, to relax.
Dismisses Leland's concerns about the war and the ethics of news coverage with a grin and a comment on the vicious circle of sensationalism.
Recognizes the media's tendency to follow each other and exploits it to keep his paper competitive.
Dismisses the seriousness of the civil war situation despite warnings from Leland.
Confidently asserts his editorial choices and social control over his environment (e.g., presence of Georgie and other girls).
Ignores Leland's concerns about journalistic integrity and the reality of the news.
Invites friends and acquaintances to socialize, plays piano and encourages singing, includes others in the fun.
Notices Leland's unhappiness and draws him aside to offer a job opportunity suited to his interests.
Organizes social gatherings, engages others with charm and humor, and offers a job opportunity to Leland that suits his interests.
Forgets the name of the young lady he is referring to, indicating a lapse in attention or memory.
Offers to get girls and arranges tickets for a night out, engaging in lighthearted social plans.
Dismisses Leland's concern about charm not being enough, insists it matters to him, and resumes dancing, showing playful confidence.
Makes others laugh heartily at Rector's, creating a joyful and friendly atmosphere.
Calls down to Leland and Bernstein saying 'You don't expect me to keep any of those promises, do you?'
Confidently arranges social plans and handles interactions with charm and humor, making others laugh heartily.
Dismisses Leland's warning about charm not being enough, showing possible overconfidence or lack of insight.
Wants Leland to go to Europe with him to have fun together.
Plans a trip to Europe and arranges for companions, showing foresight and social planning.
Does not personally engage in the conversation or defend himself, relying on others to speak for him.
Married for love and sought love from everyone, including voters.
Lost love because he didn't have any to give despite wanting it.
Married for love and pursued politics driven by desire for love and approval.
Failed to maintain meaningful personal relationships despite public success.
Confronts the President about corrupt oil leases, passionately defending the public's interest.
Screams at the President, showing intense anger and tension.
Confronts the President directly and passionately about the oil scandal, showing determination and willingness to take on powerful interests.
Screams and loses composure during the meeting with the President, which may undermine his effectiveness and appear unprofessional.
Manages to control a potentially hysterical outburst and bows politely to the President despite disagreement.
Builds to a frenzy and insists on his own opinion, showing intolerance to opposing views.
Smiles and agrees to let the headline slide, showing friendliness and good-natured behavior with colleagues.
Engages in a tense political discussion, insists on his viewpoint about public oil lands, but fails to persuade the President and is dismissed.
Controls his emotions to avoid an outburst and bows politely despite frustration.
Confidently approves a newspaper headline under time pressure, showing decisiveness and leadership in the newsroom.
Orders to get the news story on the street despite negative implications.
Responds quickly to a crisis by instructing to get the news story on the street immediately.
Commands staff to write a front page editorial praising the assassinated President as a great man, despite others' doubts.
Commands staff to immediately produce a front page editorial on the President's assassination, showing decisiveness and control in a crisis.
Dismisses cautionary advice from Reilly to wait for more information, potentially acting prematurely.
Engages in a tense exchange with Leland about the President's greatness, revealing possible emotional bias affecting judgment.
Insists on exposing fraud and fighting for the people's rights despite public backlash.
Dismisses public opinion and blames the crowd for misunderstanding him, showing little empathy.
Commands the newspaper to run a story portraying the president as a martyr, prioritizing his agenda over sensitivity.
Expresses concern by saying 'I've got to think of Emily.'
Maintains composure and focus on work despite chaotic and violent events around him, including staff panic and Bernstein being attacked.
Expresses personal concern (thinking of Emily) during a critical professional moment, potentially distracting from duties.
Smiles ingratiatingly and speaks kindly to Leland who is drunk.
Offers to get Leland coffee and tries to ease tension gently.
Acknowledges Leland's concerns without cruelty, offers to get drunk too to relate.
Listens quietly and seriously when Leland brings up personal issues.
Responds kindly and patiently to Leland's drunken state, offers to get coffee, and tries to maintain a calm conversation despite tension.
Attempts to defuse conflict with humor and self-deprecation by saying he'll get drunk too, showing emotional intelligence and confidence.
Does not immediately react defensively or aggressively to Leland's refusal to write a good review or his desire to leave, showing restraint and control.
Allows Leland to express dissatisfaction and does not force his own agenda, indicating a level of diplomatic skill.
Responds sharply to Leland's concerns about Emily leaving, shows no empathy.
Does not answer or engage with Leland's explanations about Emily's feelings and isolation.
Dismisses the personal impact of his actions on Emily, emphasizing a harsh worldview.
Responds sharply and confidently to Leland's accusations, asserting control over the situation.
Fails to respond thoughtfully to Leland's concerns about his marriage and personal relationships, showing emotional detachment or avoidance.
Dismisses Leland's warnings about Emily leaving and custody issues without apparent strategic consideration.
Shows awareness of the personal nature of conflicts but does not engage constructively to resolve them.
Expresses strong convictions about fighting complacency and corruption in government, showing concern for the rights of the American people.
Talks about the people of the United States as though they belonged to him and implies a paternalistic attitude.
Makes a passionate, articulate argument about fighting complacency and corruption in government, showing insight and conviction.
Refuses to engage emotionally or respond directly to Leland's personal criticisms, maintaining composure.
Appears unable or unwilling to address Leland's deeper personal accusations about his relationships and social interactions.
Smiles gently when talking about Chicago despite warning about its harshness.
Says he will do nothing if Emily doesn't love him, showing resignation rather than bitterness.
Hardens his face when discussing Emily, indicating emotional distance.
Dismisses Emily's feelings and social concerns as trivial, showing lack of empathy.
Claims he has already left Emily and will live without her, suggesting emotional detachment and self-reliance.
Responds to Leland's concerns with calm confidence and a little smile, showing emotional control and self-assurance.
Admits he will do nothing if Emily doesn't love him, indicating a clear boundary and acceptance of reality.
Dismisses emotional vulnerability and frames love in pragmatic, somewhat cold terms, showing a strategic but potentially flawed understanding of personal relationships.
Notices Leland is hurt by a thrown rock and asks if he is hurt.
Offers to increase Leland's salary after the incident.
Uses charm to deflect serious conversation and suggests drinking another brandy.
Leans out of the cab to discuss salary with Leland, showing some concern for his well-being.
Focuses on love 'on my terms,' implying a self-centered view of relationships.
Uses charm to deflect emotional tension and maintain social grace.
Notices Leland's injury and shows concern, indicating awareness and care.
Attempts to negotiate a better salary for Leland, showing leadership and fairness.
Fails to immediately notice the rock hitting Leland, indicating a momentary lack of situational awareness.
Insists the nurses leave to have a private moment with Emily, showing concern and urgency.
Tries to comfort Emily about political threats and the president's condition, attempting reassurance.
Becomes exasperated and stops when Emily does not respond, showing frustration.
Uncomfortably reassures Emily that threatening letters won't harm their child, showing protective concern.
Firmly orders the nurse to leave the room to speak privately with Emily, showing decisiveness and control.
Attempts to reassure Emily about political and personal threats, showing awareness of the situation and trying to manage crisis.
Becomes exasperated and stops when he realizes he is not making progress with Emily, indicating some frustration and possible lack of emotional intelligence in this moment.
Shows uncertainty and discomfort when Emily questions the threatening letters, revealing vulnerability and lack of full confidence.
Reassures Emily about Junior's safety despite his own discomfort.
Bites his lips and refrains from speaking further when Emily looks at him, showing restraint.
Looks on unwanted and ignored as Emily comforts the baby, then walks out with tightened lips.
Works intensely at night and decisively orders withdrawal of support, showing focus but no warmth.
Arranges guards in front of the house to protect from anonymous threats.
Bites his lips and refrains from speaking when confronted by Emily, showing hesitation or discomfort.
Reassures Emily confidently about the President's condition despite uncertainty.
Works with usual intensity at his desk, showing focus and dedication.
Forgets or is unaware of a $25,000 bonus check made out to Leland, showing a lapse in attention to financial details.
Tears up the 'Declaration of Principles' paper without reading it.
Delivers an inspiring speech promising honest governance and prosecution of corruption, eliciting enthusiastic support.
Tears up the 'Declaration of Principles' without reading it, showing impulsiveness and disregard for stated ideals.
Delivers a confident and effective campaign speech, demonstrating political skill and ability to inspire a crowd.
Pats Reilly on the shoulder while walking through the crowd.
Does not respond to Reilly's hopeful inquiry about giving a break to Buffalo.
Engages in friendly conversation with Bernstein and Reilly, expressing cautious optimism.
Delivers a great speech that impresses civic leaders and gains strong political support.
Responds modestly and confidently to praise without arrogance.
Does not respond to Reilly's inquiry about giving a political break, showing restraint or strategic silence.
Expresses cautious optimism about the election results and political prospects.
Shows awareness of political opponents' fear and uses it to bolster his own position.
Rushes toward Emily and Junior, puts arm around Junior's shoulder, greets them warmly.
Insists on going home with Emily despite her preference to send Junior home by car.
Dismisses Emily's request to make a call with her, saying it can wait.
Engages with Bernstein's feedback about his gubernatorial run, listens politely and encourages him to speak.
Dismisses Emily's insistence on making a call immediately, saying it can wait.
Insists on being told what Emily has in mind and chooses to accompany her to the apartment.
Looks at Emily searchingly for enlightenment during the cab ride, showing concern and attentiveness.
Makes a light, somewhat teasing comment about Emily's flair for melodrama.
Insists on being told exactly what Emily has in mind and decides to accompany her to the address, showing engagement and control over the situation.
Looks at Emily in search of enlightenment during the cab ride, indicating a desire to understand but also some uncertainty.
Comments on Emily's flair for melodrama, showing awareness and a degree of skepticism.
Threatens Rogers with violence, disregarding Emily's disgust and the potential consequences.
Threatens Rogers impulsively and aggressively without apparent strategic consideration.
Stops when Emily expresses concern, showing some awareness of social consequences.
Mocks Rogers by sarcastically calling him a gentleman with scorn.
Accuses Rogers of being a cheap, crooked grafter and dismisses his concern for family.
Confidently asserts he will be elected governor and attempts to control the conversation.
Dismisses Rogers with scorn and insults rather than addressing the political threat directly.
Refuses to be blackmailed and faces accusations calmly, showing confidence in the public's judgment.
Allows Susan to be harshly told to shut up by Rogers without intervening.
Refuses to be blackmailed and confidently challenges Rogers, showing defiance and trust in public opinion.
Dismisses the threat without apparent preparation or counter-strategy, potentially underestimating the danger.
Refuses to be intimidated by the blackmailer, insists on facing the story head-on.
Dismisses Emily's concerns about the impact on family, shows little empathy.
Refuses to be intimidated by a blackmailer and insists the story will be published but it won't stop him.
Dismisses concerns from Emily and Susan about the impact of the story on his family and political standing, showing some denial or lack of strategic caution.
Refuses to listen to others, becomes enraged, and demands to be left alone.
Insists on making decisions alone, rejecting support or counsel.
Insists on making decisions alone and refuses to listen to others' advice or reason.
Becomes enraged and screams at others, showing loss of control and poor emotional regulation.
Confidently asserts he knows exactly what he is doing despite others' concerns.
Rushes to the door and orders Susan and Emily to get out.
Screams and threatens Rogers with prison.
Allows Susan to snuggle into his shoulder quietly despite his rage.
Rushes to the door and angrily orders Susan and Emily to leave, showing loss of control and impulsiveness.
Dismisses Rogers's warning and threatens him loudly, revealing inability to manage conflict calmly.
Shows confidence in his identity and status by declaring 'I'm Charles Foster Kane' and denying wrongdoing.
Despite accusations of fraud at the polls, Kane manages to secure a significant number of votes, indicating political influence and strategic capability.
Shows inconsistency and unpredictability in his statements and behavior toward the public, causing confusion and resentment.
Maintains control over cheap public services like ice and streetcars, demonstrating practical management of resources.
His attitude alienates people who feel manipulated and undervalued, suggesting poor interpersonal or leadership skills.
His political and social returns are failing; he is described as finished politically and socially.
He exerts control over personal lives and expects gratitude despite erratic behavior.
Is heard typing busily and finishing the notice when others are struggling or incapacitated.
Fires Leland abruptly without looking up or showing emotion.
Typing briskly and efficiently, finishing a piece with skill and quiet passion.
Firing Leland abruptly without looking up, maintaining composure.
Almost bumps into Susan and then glares at her when she laughs at his injury.
Engages in light teasing with Susan about her toothache and appearance.
Avoids collision with Susan by changing his course, showing situational awareness.
Steps on a loose plank, causing injury and mud on himself.
Complains about poor sidewalk maintenance and corruption, indicating awareness of civic issues.
Reacting with irritation and glares when laughed at, showing poor emotional control.
Thanks Susan when she offers to get hot water to wash his face.
Rushes to take the basin from Susan to prevent her from carrying it awkwardly.
Shoves the photograph aside carelessly, causing Susan to grab it to prevent it from falling.
Apologizes after Susan points out the photograph belongs to her deceased parents.
Thanks Susan politely and follows her to wash up without hesitation.
Rushes to take the basin from Susan to help her, showing attentiveness and quick response.
Accidentally shoves a photograph to one side, nearly causing it to fall.
Asks where the soap is, showing practical awareness and initiative.
Engages playfully with Susan, thanks her sincerely, and shows concern for her pain.
Encourages Susan to face him gently despite her distress, showing patience and care.
Fumbles with the soap, letting it slip and hit himself.
Acknowledges Susan's pain and tries to help by brushing off mud and thinking of a solution.
Shows some impatience or lack of tact when telling Susan to turn around and look at him, repeating the command without immediate success.
Wiggles his ears to make Susan smile and encourages her to smile.
Engages in playful shadowgraph drawing with Susan, showing patience and lightheartedness.
Looks squarely at Susan and asks if she likes him despite not knowing who he is.
Acknowledges mutual loneliness with Susan, showing emotional openness.
Shares personal and sentimental thoughts about his mother and youth, showing vulnerability.
Engages in light teasing and playful conversation with Susan, smiling and showing interest.
Asks Susan about her age and background in a friendly, non-intrusive manner.
Confidently engages in conversation, shows self-awareness about his past and current life, attempts to connect with Susan by sharing personal history.
Appears slightly embarrassed and hesitant when recalling his birth year and personal details, stops mid-sentence and changes mood, indicating some discomfort or lack of ease.
Sympathetically inquires about Susan's singing and encourages her to sing despite her bashfulness.
Gently teases Susan about having no alibi to avoid singing, showing playful encouragement.
Encourages Susan to sing despite her hesitancy, showing confidence and social skill in putting her at ease.
Listens attentively and is relaxed and at ease during Susan's singing, demonstrating emotional intelligence and self-assurance.
Uses gentle humor ('Don't tell me your toothache is bothering you again?') to coax Susan into singing, showing interpersonal skill.
Built an opera house for Susan and arranged music lessons to support her singing career.
Insists Matisti continue training Susan despite the teacher's objections, showing disregard for expert opinion and Susan's actual talent.
Reassures Susan by telling her Matisti will listen to reason, attempting to comfort her.
Insists that Matisti train Susan's voice despite the teacher's objections, showing confidence and control over the situation.
Uses his knowledge of the newspaper business to intimidate Matisti and influence his decision, demonstrating strategic thinking and influence.
Ignores expert opinion about Susan's lack of talent, potentially risking failure in the opera venture.
Refuses to be persuaded, dismisses Matisti's attempt to reason.
Listens silently and intently to Susan's poor singing despite audience ridicule.
Refuses to be persuaded, confidently asserts his position ('You can't.' and 'I knew you'd see it my way.')
Sits silently and listens to a poor performance, showing no immediate intervention or corrective action
Applauds furiously and supports Susan despite the audience's cold reception.
Responds to Susan's concerns with cold menace and refuses to explain his reasons.
Starts to applaud furiously despite the polite and dying applause from the audience, showing an attempt to support Susan publicly.
Ignores Susan's clear distress and practical concerns about her singing and public embarrassment, insisting on his own reasons without explanation.
Displays cold menace when confronting Susan, indicating a controlling and possibly intimidating approach rather than a constructive or skillful one.
Insists Susan continue singing despite her fear, eyes frightening her.
Rushes to Susan's side when she is found in distress and orders to get a doctor.
Insists Susan continue singing despite her fear, showing forcefulness and control.
Uses his newspaper empire to promote Susan's career across multiple cities, demonstrating strategic use of resources.
Commands Raymond to break into Susan's room and immediately calls for a doctor when she is found unwell, showing decisiveness and quick response in a crisis.
Stays by Susan's bedside, attentive and concerned during her illness.
Expresses confusion about Susan's mistake but remains calm and supportive.
Listens carefully to Dr. Corey, follows medical advice, stays with Susan to support her recovery.
Misjudges Susan's condition by calling her mistake 'silly' and underestimates her emotional struggle.
Angrily encourages Susan to fight the audience but then apologizes and gently pats her hand, reassuring her she won't have to fight anymore and smiling.
Responds to Susan's sarcastic and somewhat lonely remarks about living in a palace at the end of the world by recalling that she always wanted to live in a palace.
Responds to Susan's despair with anger and determination, insisting that one must fight the audience to succeed.
Comforts Susan by promising she won't have to fight the audience anymore and claims it's their loss, showing confidence and reassurance.
Answers Susan's question about the time promptly and accurately, showing awareness of his environment and responsibilities.
Fails to engage meaningfully with Susan's sarcastic and melancholic remarks about their isolated lifestyle, showing a lack of emotional intelligence or awareness.
Looks at Susan smilingly but then ignores her repeated requests to go back.
Suggests having a picnic and inviting everybody as a nice change after a party.
Looks at Susan steadily but not hostilely during her outburst.
Looks at Susan smilingly and turns back to his work, ignoring her pleas.
Engages in a calm, steady conversation with Susan despite her anger, showing emotional control.
Suggests a picnic and social event to change the atmosphere, showing initiative and planning.
Repeats his invitation calmly despite Susan's sarcastic and hostile response, showing patience and confidence.
Invites everyone to a picnic and arranges accommodations.
Pats Susan lightly on the shoulder when giving instructions.
Introduces his son to Bernstein, attempting social connection.
Responds to Susan's anger and complaints with a calm, somewhat dismissive tone.
Interrupts Susan and asserts authority over the picnic rules.
Delegates the task of making arrangements for the picnic to Susan, showing organizational ability.
Introduces his son to Bernstein, indicating social awareness and confidence.
Responds calmly and logically to Susan's anger by pointing out the situation (being in a tent) and asking her to speak normally.
Interrupts Susan and asserts his authority quickly during her complaint about guests bringing drinks, showing decisiveness.
Speaks gently to Susan, acknowledging her as his wife.
Says he only wants what Susan wants.
Interrupts Susan and demands she stop speaking, rising in anger.
Attempts to assert control over Susan by telling her to stop and running her life.
Tries to de-escalate conflict gently and expresses willingness to discuss issues later.
Fails to effectively communicate or understand Susan's feelings, leading to escalation.
Says 'Whatever I do - I do - because I love you' to Susan.
Slaps Susan across the face during an argument.
Refuses to apologize after hitting Susan.
Hesitates and shows a startled look when confronted with Susan leaving.
Walks away impulsively after hearing Mrs. Kane is leaving.
Dismisses Susan's accusations confidently and asserts his love for her.
Slaps Susan in anger, escalating conflict rather than resolving it.
Refuses to apologize and tries to control Susan's decision to leave.
Hesitates and is visibly unsettled when informed Susan is leaving, showing lack of emotional control.
Impulsively walks out of the room without addressing the situation effectively.
Begs Susan not to leave, shows vulnerability and desperation.
Physically bars Susan's way, tries to control her actions.
Physically bars Susan's way and pleads with her not to leave, showing desperation and emotional vulnerability.
Attempts to control Susan's decision by force of presence rather than reasoned discussion.
Expresses his feelings openly and tries to negotiate by promising to respect Susan's wishes, indicating some emotional intelligence.
Announces divorce from his wife in a public statement, emphasizing a 'peaceful and friendly agreement'.
Announces a divorce publicly with a formal statement, showing control over his personal affairs and media.
His wife leaves him and plans to sue for divorce, indicating possible failure in managing personal relationships.
Destroys Susan's bedroom in a silent rage, smashing her belongings and creating a shambles.
Accepts the snow globe from Raymond sheepishly and leaves the room quietly.
In a silent rage, Kane destroys Susie's room with tremendous speed and surprising strength, showing physical capability and decisiveness.
Despite his rage and destruction, Kane fails to pick up the glass snow globe himself and needs Raymond's help, indicating a moment of physical or emotional weakness.
Kane's destructive outburst is wordless and uncontrolled, suggesting a lack of emotional control and poor judgment in handling personal issues.
Instructs Raymond to close and lock the door, then quietly repeats 'Keep it locked' while appearing almost in a trance and speaking very quietly to himself.
Gently shakes the glass ball and watches the snowflakes settle, showing a moment of quiet reflection.
Walks slowly down the corridor, servants give way and watch him pass, indicating a distant or possibly intimidating presence.
Stands nearby with Raymond, looking on as workmen lower the coffin of his son, showing a somber, possibly respectful presence.
Instructs Raymond to close and lock the door, showing control over the situation.
Handles the glass ball with care and seems absorbed in it, indicating focus and deliberate behavior.
Speaks very quietly, almost to himself, which may indicate withdrawal or lack of clear communication.
Slowly walks off, with servants watching him as an old man, suggesting diminished presence or authority.
Engages Raymond in a personal conversation about poetry and memories of his wife and family.
Appears distant and detached, looking through people and objects rather than engaging directly.
Shares a reflective and somewhat vulnerable moment about his past and mortality.
Engages in a somewhat confused and distracted conversation about poetry and the wall, showing signs of mental decline and detachment from reality.
Demonstrates knowledge about the origin of the wall and its historical significance (Persia, belonged to a king).
Appears unable to communicate clearly or effectively, confusing those around him (Raymond thinks he is 'off his trolley').
Calls tributary kings together and offers them treasures, asking only for one more day on earth.
The kings stand silent and look at the ground, ignoring his offer.
Stares at the wall, seemingly distant and disconnected in his final moments.
Calls tributary kings together and offers them vast treasures to gain more time on earth, showing ambition and leadership.
Despite his offers and power, the tributary kings remain silent and he ultimately dies, indicating failure to achieve his goal.
Stares beyond the wall, seemingly lost in thought or vision, possibly indicating deep reflection or detachment.
He went right on buying - right up to the end, collecting many things.
His last words 'Rosebud' remain a mystery even to the investigator, indicating a lack of clear communication or leaving unresolved questions.
Was tolerant and lived by 'Live and Let Live' motto.
Had no use for anybody who disagreed with him on any point, no matter how small.
Was a loving husband and a good father.
Broke his oldest friend's heart like you'd throw away a cigarette.
Got everything he wanted, showing ability to achieve goals.
Lost everything he had, indicating failure to maintain success.
